item.title: Xah Talk Show Ep710 Emacs Lisp Coding, lookup grokipedia, goto line in next pane
item.description:
youtube

Video Summary (Generated by AI, Reviewed by Human.) This video is an Emacs Lisp coding session focused on creating and fixing two commands: lookup-grokipedia and go-to-char/go-to-line. The speaker begins by demonstrating the go-to-line command, which allows users to jump to a specific line number in another pane (0:37). He then introduces Grokipedia, a new encyclopedia by Elon Musk, explaining that it aims to provide a different perspective on "power-sensitive" topics compared to Wikipedia, which the speaker claims contains "fake news" on such subjects (11:12). He demonstrates this by comparing Wikipedia and Grokipedia entries for "Gamergate" (16:15). The speaker also mentions that for non-political topics like programming or mathematics, Grokipedia currently offers plain text versions of Wikipedia articles without illustrations or interlinks (21:06). He then proceeds to code the lookup-grokipedia command in Emacs Lisp, demonstrating how to grab the current word under the cursor and construct a URL to search Grokipedia (25:02). Finally, the speaker fixes a bug in his go-to-line command (32:02) and briefly discusses his use of multiple web browsers (35:16) and his Emacs Lisp packages, including Xah Fly Keys (2:51) and "Xah Emacs Lisp Mode" (39:18). Notes at http ://xahlee .info/talk_show/xah_talk_show_ep710.html Copy the link, remove spaces, paste the link in browser tab. Google Chrome and Firefox browsers censor websites by auto adding s in http and says the site Secure Connection Failed. Use Brave Browser or Safari.

item.description:
youtube

Emacs users have access to a wide network of installable packages. These packages can be used to extend the base functionality of Emacs, so you can save time, do more, and have fun. EMACS FOR WRITERS HANDBOOK: https://chris-maiorana.kit.com/products/emacs-for-writers chrismaiorana.com

item.title: emacs literate org mode config for your init.el
item.description:
youtube

instead of having one big emacs init.el you can split the file up into code blocks each under their own heading in an org file and then tangle or write out all the code blocks to a file inj this video i show you how to use org demarcate block to split a code block into multiple new blocks which can be filed under their own headings we then use noweb-ref in a org properties drawer to apply a name to all the code blocks under a subtree which can then be tangled using another source code block that references those blocks the advantage of this method is that you can tangle the code blocks to multiple locations instead of tangling the entire document nixos dotfiles https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/nixos-dotfiles/blob/master/nixos-dotfiles.org changelog https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/changelog org demarcate block https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/cerberus/blob/master/emacs/org-demarcate-block.org

item.title: Why I Use Emacs for Ontologies (and How to Memorize a HUGE Knowledge Graph) [AMA #1]
item.description:
youtube

Why would an Ontology Engineer skip tools like Protege and TopBraid Composer and stick with a 'plain' text editor like Emacs? And how do you manage a complex knowledge graph with thousands of classes and properties without relying on memory alone? Those were two great questions from FredBlok4308, and I'm answering them in this video. I dive into my personal workflow, explaining the history and practical reasons for choosing a text-based approach (hint: it's a historical happy accident that was supported by it being fun, fully customizable, and better than the other options I tried). I also reveal the secret to taming graph complexity, which involves good modular design, the "use it or lose it" principle, and leveraging SPARQL queries to serve as your method for learning the vocabula. Whether you're a Semantic Web veteran or just starting with knowledge graphs, this covers the critical strategies for scaling your data modeling efforts.

item.title: Emacs eglot and language servers for auto completion
item.description:
youtube

Eglot is an Emacs package that works as an lcp client that connects to a language server to provide features like auto complete, go to definition, find all references etc. You can install language server for languages like bash, python and dozens more and then map a mode like python to the python lsp server, so whenever you open a python file it starts the python lsp server automatically lsp servers notes https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/cerberus/blob/master/emacs/lsp-servers.org emacs eglot https://github.com/joaotavora/eglot bash-language-server https://github.com/bash-lsp/bash-language-server python-lsp-server https://github.com/python-lsp/python-lsp-server nixd https://github.com/nix-community/nixd nixos emacs config https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/nixos-dotfiles/tree/master/.config/emacs debian emacs config https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/debian-dotfiles/tree/master/.config/emacs language server protocol https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/

In this video, we will look at how you can configure your Emacs install with the magic configuration file. The "config" holds your user preferences. It's coded with Emacs Lisp. You don't have to be an expert in Elisp to get started. You can start with my "darkstar" config or piece together examples from the Internet. STARTER CONFIG: https://github.com/cryptstopher/darkstar EMACS FOR WRITERS HANDBOOK: https://chris-maiorana.kit.com/products/emacs-for-writers chrismaiorana.com

item.title: buffer-restore.el - Save and Restore Emacs Window Layouts with Named Sessions
item.description:
youtube

https://github.com/emacselements/buffer-restore Quick demo of buffer-restore.el, an Emacs package for manual session management. Unlike desktop-save-mode, buffer-restore lets you save multiple named sessions and workspaces, giving you explicit control over when to save and restore your layouts. Key Features: ‚Ä¢ Save/restore single frame layouts (sessions) ‚Ä¢ Save/restore multiple frames with positions (workspaces) ‚Ä¢ Preserves exact PDF pages, EPUB chapters, and cursor positions ‚Ä¢ Perfect for switching between different work contexts Commands shown: - buffer-restore-save-session - buffer-restore-load-session - buffer-restore-save-workspace - buffer-restore-load-workspace ,#emacs #productivity #opensource #plato #republic

item.title: show doc for candidate of complete of company/corfu in Emacs
item.description:
youtube

I just learned that we can show the document for the candidate as we move through the candidates list of company/corfu. For company, it requires either of the following packages to show document for candidate 1. https://github.com/company-mode/company-quickhelp or 2. https://github.com/sebastiencs/company-box For Corfu, not additional package is needed. just add (corfu-popupinfo-mode) in "init" (use-package corfu :custom (corfu-cycle t) (corfu-preview-current nil) :init (global-corfu-mode) (corfu-popupinfo-mode) ;; this is for show document for candidate )

item.title: "It Works": More Adventures with Racket and Emacs
item.description:
youtube

Greg Hendershott "It Works": More Adventures with Racket and Emacs The Emacs package "racket-mode" has continued to evolve its design and features. Among other things, it allows multiple local and remote back ends, has a redesigned "lossless" REPL, supports modern Emacs UI completion annotations, and enables lang-driven editing. Most recently the step debugger has gotten some attention. Bio: Greg Hendershott has a useless degree in philosophy, a background in the music software industry, and a decade working in the open source Racket and Emacs communities. Tedious details are available at greghendershott.com.

item.title: Treesitter "show definition" in C with Emacs
item.description:
youtube

I have given up on the complexity of LSPs, I just use the _amazing_ treesitter library instead: parsing my code as I type it's very fast and can do nearly everything that an LSP can do but this way I just have to deal with programming Emacs, which is super easy. I've got this on the Internet over here: https://tangled.org/@nicferrier.bsky.social/nic-emacs-treesitter-stuff There's a readme which makes an attempt to explain how to try and use it but it's still very much a work in progress. My main focus is C, because that's what I'm programming in mostly. So if you're a C programmer and an Emacs user and you want to try it - then download it from tangled and give mea shout if it doesn't work.

item.title: Emacs gptel and mcp-searxng enable web search for your llm's with searxng
item.description:
youtube

The emacs gptel package lets you use local llm's with ollama as well as online llm's like Gemini however the issue is the models dont have web access so they have a cut off in their knowledge based on when they were built Installing the mcp.el package with gptel provides the mcp protocol to work with mcp servers this allows us to use the mcp-searxng server that works with the searxng self hosted search engine to enable web searches for our llm's The mcp-searxng server also lets you download web pages as well The mcp-nixos server allows us to search for nixos packages from within Emacs, as well other tools to show the latest channel and other useful stuff The mcp.el package works with models that support tools using ollama like llama3.1 or with online models like Gemini docker.el lets you manage your podman or docker container from within Emacs, and the dockerfile-mode package provides syntax highlighting for Dockerfiles https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/cerberus/blob/master/emacs/gptel-mcp-severs.org https://github.com/karthink/gptel?tab=readme-ov-file#model-context-protocol-mcp-integration https://github.com/lizqwerscott/mcp.el https://github.com/Silex/docker.el https://github.com/spotify/dockerfile-mode https://github.com/ihor-sokoliuk/mcp-searxng https://github.com/utensils/mcp-nixos Seaxng search engine podman install https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qAKmxK6juwI https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/cerberus/blob/master/searxng/searxng-podman.org https://github.com/NapoleonWils0n/nixos-dotfiles

item.title: Emacs For Writers Unit 6: Welcome to Org Mode
item.description:
youtube

In this video, you will finally get a glimpse of Org Mode, the mode that's more than a mode. It's a whole productivity suite, but even if you don't use the productivity tools, it's a powerful way to organize and compose rich outlines and beautifully written documents. All the while, you can be cool while doing it. Check it out. EMACS FOR WRITERS HANDBOOK: https://chris-maiorana.kit.com/products/emacs-for-writers VIDEO ON INSTALL ORG CONTRIB PACKAGE INSTALLATION: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FW8CkvZtNgY chrismaiorana.com

item.title: Fulltext, semantic text and image search in Emacs
item.description:
youtube

I show my new org-db package for full and semantic text and image search in Emacs. This package indexes your org-files and provides several ways to search them by org-heading, full text with fts5 in sqlite, vector search for semantic search, and searching images from textual descriptions using CLIP! The whole project was "vibe-coded" with Claude Code over about 7 days. It is still in an alpha stage of development, but I have been using it for a few days now, and am pretty happy with it. https://github.com/jkitchin/org-db-v3

item.title: Emacs Adventure | Exploring Vanilla Emacs
item.description:
youtube

üî• Turn your terminal into a coding playground! Ever wondered what makes a 40-year-old text editor still relevant in 2025? Join me as we dive into GNU Emacs and explore the tools of the trade! What You'll Learn: ‚úÖ Install Emacs on Linux, Mac, and Windows ‚úÖ Master essential navigation and keybindings ‚úÖ Set up Python development with LSP (Language Server Protocol) ‚úÖ Code JavaScript with intelligent features ‚úÖ Create HTML/CSS projects with web-mode ‚úÖ Build your first custom Emacs configuration ‚ö° Quick Start Commands: sudo apt install emacs # Linux brew install --cask emacs # Mac ,# Windows: Download from gnu.org/software/emacs ,# Essential Keys C-x C-f # Open file C-x C-s # Save C-x C-c # Quit C-s # Search üìö Resources: - GNU Emacs Official: https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/ - MELPA Packages: https://melpa.org/ - LSP Mode Documentation: https://emacs-lsp.github.io/lsp-mode/ - Org Mode Documentation: https://orgmode.org/index.html üéØ Perfect for: - Developers curious about emacs - Anyone wanting a single app to do everything in development workflow ‚è±Ô∏è Timestamps: üì± Connect With Me: - Subscribe for weekly tech experiments - LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/kiran-capoor/ - Twitter: https://x.com/ctrlalttechwk üé¨ Filmed with: OBS Studio, Terminal recordings at 1920x1080 No editors were harmed in the making of this video. All tools have their place in the developer ecosystem! üòÑ Difficulty: Beginner Prerequisites: Basic terminal familiarity Support the Channel: If this helped you discover something new, the best support is hitting subscribe and sharing with fellow developers who love experimenting with their tools or buying me a coffee - https://buymeacoffee.com/ctrlalttech Remember: In Engineering, there are no failures ‚Äì only discoveries! üß™‚ö° ,#emacs #texteditor #ctrlalttech

item.description:
youtube

In this video, I show how I turned a handful of small little steps into an expedited git clone flow. Snippet and details at corresponding blog post https://xenodium.com/bending-emacs-episode-3-git-clone-the-lazy-way With enough interest, I'll continue making videos. If you enjoy this content, please don't forget to like, susbcribe to my channel, and leave me comments. Thank you!

item.title: Modeling bioreactor data with an LLM in Emacs
item.description:
youtube

We show how to use an LLM to examine synthetic data from a bioreactor for biomass and substrate concentrations over time. We use the LLM to graph the data with Python, suggest models for the data, and then to fit the data to extract parameters. There are a few wrinkles with the specific integration of emacs-jupyter and org-mode, but we get to a satisfactory result at the end.

item.title: Ollama tool use demo on Android Emacs 30.1
item.description: youtube
